review_title: If you hold a Masters or PhD your income is good
job_title: Computer Science Teacher in Longueuil, QC
pros:
When you have all material prepared, you can manage your time efficiently and have free time.
Free gym.
Excellent work environment
On vacations (ends May-ends August) I used to work programming.
cons:
Some schedules where classes are early, late, or have gaps between classes
New assigned courses, where you don't have experience, you have to learn and prepare all the material(slides, tests, labs)
One week before starting classes you might be assigned a new course :(

pros: Academic freedom for lecturers. Small class size.
cons: Little to no support or communication from admin and faculty. No meetings, no help with student issues, no communication or meetings amont teachers, who are left to fend for themselves. Assigned courses without enough prep time, support, direction.

pros: SSQ health insurance with option for dental, life insurance, rebates for home and auto insurance. Your salary is divided up into 12 months so that you get paid throughout the summer as well. It is a government funded academic institution.
cons:
Toxic work environment that includes bullying, harassment, and mistreatment of faculty, staff, and students (particularly victims of sexual assault on campus). Sadly, these issues stem from a lack of adherence to provincial laws and regulations not only from management, but often from fellow staff members and faculty. Abuse can go unchecked for decades.

Whilst there are some students who are equally to blame for this toxicity, in the end, they get away with it because of the culture of the institution as a whole. The few teachers, faculty, or students who avoid these issues are the minority. Finally, compared to our university and college counterparts across Canada, we are also under-paid.

BIPOC members are particularly targeted and discriminated against as our teachers who actively and vocally support equal rights. Much of the issues stem from institutional racism and is compounded by Québec's xenophobic policies and legislation.  It's a lose-lose situation as a result.

pros: Small place. We know each other. Not too much bureaucracy. A lot of academic freedom. Nice colleagues and students.
cons: Total lack of diversity in top leadership roles at the campus in Saint-Lambert. Leadership out of date. Lack of communication from admin. A lot of problem with IT. High turnover in Human ressources.

review_title: Lots of benefits if you stick around long enough
pros: Can get hired straight-away into the day program (so without teaching Cont Ed, as is the case in other anglophone Colleges). Lots of benefits once you've worked there the equivalent of 3 years. A unionized environment!
cons: The first few semesters/years, work can be inconsistent from semester to semester, but if you stick around long enough, you will get consistent work.

pros: It's a small college with a small campus.  I'm presenting it as an advantage and it felt this way when I worked over there.  It's a very multicultural environment.
cons:
I've met 2 employees during the selection process.  There was an interview and a test.  Each one of them has told me what to say during the interview and the test.  I'm writing this here as I did not see any option where to mention it in the form on the interviews and I think it's important to say that to inform potential applicants.  

Management is paternalistic and autocratic.  Even if the campus director suggests employees that have ideas to bring them up, it is better not to bring up more than 1 or 2.   The union provides little defence to employees.

pros: Great for caring about students, providing services, updating the school
cons: Awful IT department. Technology is highly deficient and behind all the time.
